sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,Prologue to the Gentle Shepherd., in Poems, (Dumfries, 1794), 10-12.

head.title: Prologue to The Gentle Shepherd.11 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 10-12; reprinted in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 11, 1796). Allan Ramsay’s pastoral comedy The Gentle Shepherd was a staple of late eighteenth-century Scottish theatre; Turnbull’s prologue was written for the Dumfries Theatre. While the play was well-known to American readers, it had never been staged in Charleston before the performance at the City Theatre, on April 30, 1796, “under the Sanction and Patronage of the R.W. Grand Lodge of South Carolina Ancient York Masons,” when Turnbull played Bauldy and his wife played Mause.

lg.l: Sirs, I’m a Ghaist!—but dinna fear me,
I’m Ramsay’s Ghaist!22 Allan Ramsay (1686-1758), Scottish poet and author of The Gentle Shepherd. —ay, now ye’ll hear me;—
Frae sweet Elysium’s bonny bow’rs,33 In Greek mythology, the dwelling place of the blessed after death.
Where Poets pass their blissfu’ hours,
I come, and dinna scorn to tell,
Only to justify mysel’.
When Death, that camsheugh carl,44 Surly, ill-tempered man. had fell’d me,
And first Elysian fouk beheld me,
My auld blue bonnet on my head,
And hamely Caledonian55 Scottish; from Caledonia, Latin for Scotland. weed;
They cry’d, “preserve’s: what’s yon droll body,
That gangs just like a niddy noddy?66 To nod repeatedly, as when dozing (DSL).
’Tis some bit poor auld Scottish herd”:
“Na faith!” quo’ Hermes,77 In Greek mythology, messenger of the Gods as well as conductor of the dead. “he’s a Bard,
Sic as the deel a’ mae ye’ll find,
And ane of the Dramatic kind.”
Syne he pronounc’d aloud my name,
A current passport for my fame.

Then I shook hands wi’ Johny Dryden,88 Turnbull recurrently alludes to John Dryden (1631-1700), English poet and playwright. Cf. “To Morpheus,” epigraph; “Elegy I,” line 4; “Elegy IX,” line 14; “Elegy X,” line 28; and, “Pastoral I,” epigraph in Poetical Essays (1788).
And twa-three mae, wham much we pride in;

As Irish Ben,99 [GT's note: Ben Johnston.] Scotticized spelling for Ben Jonson (1572-1637), English poet and playwright of Scottish descent. Turnbull’s footnote is, perhaps, an allusion to Jonson’s The Irish Masque at Court (1616).
Wha’s, by my saul, a matchless Billy;1010 [GT's note: Shakespear.] William Shakespeare (1564-1616) was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire.
And poor Tam Oatway,1111 Thomas Otway (1652-1685), English playwright and poet. wha’ could blaw
The sweetest whistle of them a’!
And a’ that had a spunk of grace
Gied me kind welcome to the place;
But ane, wha look’d as if I stunk,
The chiel was either daft or drunk,
And though he had but little gumption,
’Twas mair than balanc’d by presumption;
Said, in a kind of leering way,
“Friend! sure ye never read a play;
Or if ye had, ’tis plain enough,
Ye ne’er could fancy sic damn’d stuff,
As Scottish Shepherds’ uncouth rhyms,
Could grace the stage and please the times”.
Guidman, quoth I, whate’er’s your name
I dinna ken, but never blame
Things as far past your comprehension,
As is the very Piece ye mention;
And though ye may think little o’t,
I’ll wager you a sterling groat,
Or, what a Poet values mair,
This wreath1212 Crown of laurels fashioned to honor poets and heroes. that I hae round my hair,
Against that wither’d twig of thine,
I’ll get applause for ilka line!
Now, Sirs, I sweat wi’ very fright,
Lest ye should hiss my play this night;
For Actors are grown sae refin’d,
They never speak it to my mind;
Sae if the Piece its beauty tine,1313 v. lose.
Ye canna say the wyte was mine:
Yet, O! be sparing for my sake,

For if ye hiss, I lose my stake!1414 Share of the play’s proceeds; an actor’s earnings typically included at least one benefit performance towards the end of a theatrical season, for which he or she chose the pieces to be performed and shared the profits from the tickets sold.
